description.plain:
Clifford Harris, Jr., better known as T.I., is a rapper, film & music producer, actor, and author from Atlanta. He is also the founder and CEO of Grand Hustle Records.

T.I. has released eleven studio albums and has had a successful acting career, starring in the films Ant-Man, Takers and ATL.

songs.full_title: About The Money by T.I. (Ft. Young Thug)
songs.title: About The Money

description.plain:
Atlanta rapper T.I teams up with neighborhood weirdo Young Thug for a summer jam about money, opulence and alligator shoes.

It was released with a weird music video directed by Kennedy Rothchild, “About the Money” features twitchy, sample-heavy production from fellow southerner and Young Thug collaborator London On Da Track.

“About the Money” was released on June 3, 2014 as the first single from T.I.’s ninth studio album, Paperwork: The Motion Picture, through Grand Hustle and Columbia Records.

In an interview with Pigeons & Planes, T.I. said the song came about when Thug “just pulled up to the studio and we went ahead and did it.”

“He has a unique style. His melody, cadences, and ability to put songs together. He can make records that translate to the market. That shit is impeccable.”

description.plain:
Originally intended for T.I.’s Trouble Man: Heavy is the Head, this track missed the cut due to issues clearing the sample of Gotye’s “Somebody I Used to Know”.

It was announced in April, 2013 that the song was going to be included as a part of the forthcoming Hustle Gang EP as the lead single, however, little to no news of the EP has been released since.

songs.full_title: That's All She Wrote by T.I. (Ft. Eminem)
songs.title: That’s All She Wrote

description.plain:
On “That’s All She Wrote,” T.I. talks about the law while Eminem talks about sex. This marks their first collaboration since “Touchdown.” The instrumental is a mellow affair, a series of guitar strums, both over staccato 808’s, allowing both rappers to take center stage.

Around Thanksgiving 2010, just a few weeks before No Mercy was officially released, a version of this song surfaced on the Internet that featured a different Eminem verse and lacked a bridge from T.I., though it’s presumably only a demo.

This track is produced by Dr. Luke, a renown contributor to T.I.’s other music.

That is all she wrote folks.

songs.full_title: Live Your Life by T.I. (Ft. Rihanna)
songs.title: Live Your Life

description.plain:
Released in 2008 on T.I.’s best-selling Paper Trail album, “Live Your Life” is a life-affirming T.I.-Rihanna tag-team that’s guaranteed to give you a boost.

The intro/outro is ripped from a Romanian song called ‘Dragoste Din Tei’ that rose to Western Hemisphere fame after being part of the meme known as the Numa Numa dance. “Live Your Life” was famously featured in The Hangover

What should I be sorry for?
Who should I be sorry to?
What should I be sorry for?
Who should I be sorry to?
The fact is you can't please everybody
You can't please everybody
What should I be sorry for?
Who should I be sorry to?

And say, "I'm sorry I'm awkward, my fault for fuckin' up the tours"

Fuck it if we did
But I hope we ain't lose no fans from it (No fans from it)
I'm a grown-ass kid, you know
I ain't never cared about no damn money
Why do we try so hard to be stars just to dodge comments?
And this that shit that'll make you call your baby mama
When you gone on half a pill
Don't know why, but that's how it is
Then you take a flight back to the crib
Y'all make love like college kids
And you say all the shit you gon' do better
We can try this shit again
'Round the time the dope wear off
You feel stupid, she feel lost

Waiting in the hallway with her arms crossed
Baby boy face full of applesauce

I can hardly breathe and

A lovely distraction, but my mind don't wanna rest

"Ooooh, you so fucking fine," I

"Ooooh, who pulls your ponytail?

songs.full_title: Dead and Gone by T.I. (Ft. Justin Timberlake)
songs.title: Dead and Gone

description.plain: In “Dead and Gone,” T.I. addresses a lot about his past and his child hood, having done some crazy things that he believe’s he should never do again.  That said, T.I. mentions that although he wouldn’t be caught doing the same things again, he, however, does not regret doing those things in his past, and believes that childish antics and pass-times are meant for children, whereas he is now an adult with a family and so much more to lose.

songs.full_title: What You Know by T.I.
songs.title: What You Know

description.plain:
Hitting #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 Rap Tracks in 2006, T.I.’s “What You Know” is a classic little ditty of the “I’m cooler than you in every possible way” variety

Judging by his impressive arrest record the self-proclaimed “King of the South” (take that Lil Flip!) may truly know “all about that”

The music video features T.I preparing for his ATL premiere. The video also features a couple of ATL scenes, including cameo appearances by the actors.

songs.full_title: Wit Me by T.I. (Ft. Lil Wayne)
songs.title: Wit Me

description.plain:
The Grand Hustle boss and the Young Money front man teamed up for an awesomely trendy new bounce track. “Wit Me” features two full verses from both of the catchy fast rapping artists.

Similar to last years hit “Ball’, Lil Tunechi and T.I. give their fans another summer smash hit. As the two faceoffed on the club style bouncy track, it is obvious that this will be a crowd favorite at their America’s Most Wanted Tour this summer.

songs.full_title: Rubber Band Man by T.I.
songs.title: Rubber Band Man

description.plain:
I used to wear rubber bands on my wrist. It was a habit from comin’ out of hustlin’, that’s just what some of us used to do. I kept doing it in the industry and people used to always ask me why, so I made a song out of it…[the rubber band] definitely represents the struggle

– T.I. (on the rubberband)

Via MTV:

“We used to wear rubber bands to signify how much money, how much blow we had,” he says of the origins of his nickname, the Rubber Band Man. “I would wear three rubber bands, and that would probably hold $5,000. If you anticipate making $20,000, you gonna have eight, nine rubber bands on both wrists.

songs.full_title: No Matter What by T.I.
songs.title: No Matter What

description.plain:
“No Matter What” was a promo single from Paper Trail, T.I’s album about coming to terms with his inevitable court trial on federal weapons charges. The song throws a couple subtle jabs towards Atlanta Rapper Shawty Lo (of D4L) at the height of their minor beef. T.I. responds to Shawty Lo’s attacks with something approaching a minor irritation. Considering he was facing up to 25 years in prison at the time, it is easy to see why T.I. wasn’t concerned with a street beef

The album was due to drop on Sept. 30, 2008; the early leak of this single to Streetcred.com and radio DJs, as well as the instantaneous street buzz, compelled Atlantic Records to move the album release up to August 12, where it made its debut at #1 on the billboard chart and was eventually certified double platinum

The track was a top 20 rotation on several rap stations nationwide, as well as a top 20 digital download single on Itunes. In addition, the video was nominated for an MTV video music award in 2008

RC

songs.full_title: Jefe by T.I. (Ft. Meek Mill)
songs.title: Jefe

description.plain:
T.I. & Meek Mill reunite over triumphant, latin-influenced production by Bangladesh.

“Jefe”–spanish for “boss”–fittingly finds the rappers boasting of their wealthy lifestyles of “brand new Bentleys, Ferraris” and dripping in the latest designer wear from “Balenci[aga], [Saint] Laurent and Givenchy”, while simultaneously stunting on their haters and nay-sayers.

songs.full_title: U Don't Know Me by T.I.
songs.title: U Don’t Know Me

description.plain:
“U Don’t Know Me”, sometimes spelled as “You Don’t Know Me” was the 2nd single for T.I.’s Urban Legend album. The song was first featured during the last minute of the “Bring Em Out” music video, in which T.I. raps the hook standing in front of a early 70’s Chevelle SS. The song was featured as the “B” side to the Bring Em Out single release.

The song was released as a single on January 5th 2005, and was very popular during the first half of 2005. It was also featured on Midnight Club Dub Edition.

The video prominently shows T.I. rapping in an auto salvage yard (junkyard), as well as him and his P$C crew around certain places of Atlanta. Towards the end of the video, there are numerous people lip syncing “you don’t know me”, as well as a fight between two females near a convenience store.

The basis of this song is to address those who wanted to ride T.I.’s coat tails and/or claim that they had a lot to do with T.I.’s success, and it went on to become a street anthem of sorts.

songs.full_title: DOPE by T.I. (Ft. Marsha Ambrosius)
songs.title: DOPE

description.plain:
“Dope” is the first official single for the tenth studio album of TIP (formerly known as T.I.), The Dime Trap, set to be released on Roc Nation. On September 16th, 2015, T.I. was interviewed by Rolling Stone magazine, where he revealed he had done “A few” sessions with Dr. Dre–this song likely emerged from one of them.

The song talks about what it feels to be in love, and its compared to being addicted to drugs.

songs.full_title: Wonderful Life by T.I. (Ft. Akon)
songs.title: Wonderful Life

description.plain:
The first verse of the song is T.I’s best friend, Philant who was shot dead, speaking down from heaven to T.I. The second verse is NOT T.I. speaking to one of his sons, but it is T.I.’s dead father speaking to T.I. from his grave. This is evident in many lines. And the third verse is T.I talking to Phil. Like he said in an interview, he dreamed about him talking to him. And also at the end he says “Til we meet in person let’s keep speaking through my verses for life”. What he means by that is he’s dead. but in the mean time, T.I will try to communicate to Phil through his verses in songs.

This song samples “Your Song” by Elton John.

songs.full_title: Stay by T.I. (Ft. Victoria Monét)
songs.title: Stay

description.plain: T.I. is rapping about his falling out marriage with “Tiny. T.I. explains that he loved her so much that he was willing to put his life on the line for her. And that T.I. understands why Tiny would cheat on T.I. due to her concerns with him drug dealing and getting in trouble with the law and serving two years in prison (one year for possessions of heavy artillery firearms and another year for violating his parole and drug possessions.) But even though T.I. is somewhat upset but content with what Tiny did, at the end of the day, that’s the love of his life and the mother of majority of T.I.’s children. And Tiny will always have a place in T.I.’s heart

songs.full_title: Ready for Whatever by T.I.
songs.title: Ready for Whatever

description.plain:
Ready For Whatever is a track off of Paper Trail explaining T.I.’s reasoning and logic to his actions in 2007, when he attempted to purchase several silenced machine guns.

Drumma Boy described in an October 22, 2014 interview with HipHopDx that T.I was required by his lawyers to alter the lyrics to the song before it could be released:

The first song that he recorded was ‘Ready For Whatever’ and he had to change the lyrics up on that song about 25 times because the lawyers were just so strict about how he was telling that particular story,” Drumma Boy says in a clip that premiered as a part of today’s DX Daily (October 22). “The first version was just all out telling you everything and then he had to kind of decode, and then he had to decode again. He had to proofread. They made him edit that song about 25 times. But just the finished results of ‘Ready For Whatever,’ if you go back and listen to it, you really see how he was feeling. You really start to understand what he was going through and why he would have so many pistols. In a life like that, having that much money, and feeling like you gotta protect your family. What else you gonna do?

songs.title_with_featured: Black Man (Ft. Meek Mill, Quavo & RaRa)

description.plain:
On the second track off the EP Us Or Else, Quavo, Rara, Meek Mill, and T.I. dive into the topic of recent police killings and put their thoughts on the issue. With the recent murders of Terence Crutcher, Alton Sterling & Philando Castile, this track is put out at a very fitting time.

On “Warzone” T.I. believed Michael George Smith was killed by the Klansmen that were supposedly in that park just the other day handing out fliers.

They left his body swangin' down in Piedmont
At a Klan rally the day before, but that ain’t mean nothing
What they say “a suicide”, I say it’s genocide

description.plain:
“Castle Walls” is the 14th track that appears on T.I.’s seventh album, No Mercy, and features guest vocals from Christina Aguilera.

Lyrically, T.I. reflects about some personal subjects in his life and how the life of a millionaire rapper doesn’t really means that everything is perfect.

[Verse 3: T.I.]

songs.full_title: We Will Not by T.I.
songs.title: We Will Not

description.plain:
Atlanta veteran T.I. released this track in the wake of dropped charges against all six officers involved in the death of 25-year-old Freddie Gray in April 2015. The booming rally cry touches on the rampant police brutality occurring in the United States of America.

Tip has been a strong advocate of the #BlackLivesMatter movement in recent months, joining protests in Atlanta, putting his money into black-owned banking systems, and appearing on Hot 97 highlighting the need for change. While at the station he announced plans to release an EP project titled Us or Else which will focus on the issues of social justice, police brutality and #BlackLivesMatter.

Zip your face up when Skateboard is on the script
Catch me in the Gap V with some BBC trunks
Flip flops, sippin' on Qream like it's punch
I push the spaceship with the chrome lady in the front
Bendin' over like she just puffed Busta’s blunt
I told y’all muh'fuckas once: I think I’m hungry
Finna eat y'all niggas' lunch, y'all niggas cunts
I’m from the Commonwealth, where wealth ain't common
When niggas roll around with chrome solvers, looking for problems
Mouth full of gold, flame when they roll
Arthritic fingers: niggas bang when they stroll
Tradin' in the hats for the cane and the gold
The golds for the chain and the 'caine was on swole
Ayo Tip, get these peon niggas told

[Verse 2: T.I.]
Still stand tall when it all falls down
Whether Hollywood Hills or a one-horse town
You should know better
There’s no better than these four letters
More than ever, niggas want me dead
'Cause they're starving and I'm getting fed
But fuck 'em anyway
I’d rather be me on my worst day
Than to be a sucker nigga on his birthday
All cake, no candles, just a living example
Ten toes down, all out, no sandals
Godfather, young Marlon Brando
Let me make sure they understand, yo
Here ye, hear ye, you wise, you fear me
Real niggas on their shine, much obliged, merci!
Everybody want to criticize him
'Bout how bad he ended up; look how bad he could've been
I could've caught a body, sold a brick to somebody
Who volunteered my information to the federales
I made it out of all of that like I ain't gon' be proud of that
So petty shit you sticking to me? Give me all you got of that
Doing this for all my niggas
Who'd rather go to prison than to let a nigga kill 'em
So we leaving this PO snub-nose in his denim
Trap or death is waiting 'round the corners that he been in
On bended knee, God forgive us, we been sinnin'
In our defense, look at the options we was given
Laying in the prison cell, staring at the ceiling
Back in this bitch again, guess they wasn't bullshitting, huh?
Still wonder where it all went wrong
Since Phil got killed, I ain't never moved on
Like I’m still in the club where the blows got thrown
When my crown fell down and I got dethroned
Bunch of niggas around, but I feel all alone
Like a piece of me is missing; guess it never came home
Probably died in the van when it all hit the fan
Save the life of a friend—we don’t all get the chance
Now, here I stand, with blood on my hands
Trying hard to explain so his mom understand
I'm at fault for the loss of the soul of a man
Only soldiers know how that'll take a toll on a man
Burdens of the world on my shoulders, heavy
Visibly composed, my emotions buried
Scary, so if I pop a pill
Smoke a blunt or take a shot, y'all, let a nigga live
Still baffled how my life unraveled
In the meantime, time just travelled
Can’t see behind the walls of my castle
Opinionated peon, son, but who asked you?
I tell you what you do: take your two cents
Kick rocks to a fountain, pitch 'em and make a wish
Shit, if wishes had wings
They’d all make it to heaven and we’d all be kings
Hahaha! If wishes had wings
They’d all make it to heaven and we’d all be kings
Yeah!
